alt_statements.statement: At my age, I’ve seen how powerful technology can be, and I enjoy using the latest gadgets—but I also know how vulnerable people can be when companies quietly harvest and sell their information. Tech companies should be legally required to collect only what they truly need, explain in plain English how that data is used, and give people real control over opting in or out. They make plenty of money; the least they can do is put users’ privacy, dignity, and safety—especially for older adults and people with disabilities—above a quick profit.

If tech companies are going to collect and profit from our data, they should be completely transparent about what they’re taking, how they’re using it, and who they’re selling it to—no hiding it in 20 pages of legal jargon. Users should have clear, simple options to opt out of data sharing and strong protections to keep that information from being abused, especially when it comes to kids and anything related to health or finances. I work hard for my family and my privacy shouldn’t be treated like a free product just because I use an app or a website.

As someone who works in health care and sees how sensitive information can be, I think tech companies should have a legal and ethical duty to collect only the data they truly need and to be completely transparent about how they use and profit from it. Users should have real, easy-to-understand control over their data—what’s collected, who it’s shared with, and the ability to opt out of monetization without losing access to essential services. I’d also like to see strong, enforceable regulations that treat data privacy more like a public health or consumer safety issue, rather than something left to corporate goodwill.

Como alguien que trabaja duro por un sueldo modesto y que no entiende bien el inglés, pienso que las compañías de tecnología tienen la responsabilidad de explicar claramente, en el idioma de la gente, qué datos están recogiendo y para qué los usan. No deberían aprovecharse de nosotros ni vender nuestra información sin un consentimiento sencillo y honesto, y el gobierno debería exigirles reglas estrictas para proteger nuestra privacidad y seguridad.

As someone who works in healthcare and sees every day how seriously we treat patient privacy, I believe tech companies should be held to similarly strict standards when handling user data. They should collect only what’s truly necessary, explain clearly and in plain language how that data will be used or sold, and give people meaningful control over opting in or out. There also needs to be real accountability—strong legal consequences—when companies misuse data or fail to protect it, because trust is too important to be treated as just another business asset.

I don’t think there’s anything wrong with tech companies using data to keep the lights on, but they ought to be straight with people about what they’re collecting and how they’re making money off it. At the very least, users should get clear, plain-language explanations and an easy way to opt out of certain uses without losing basic access to services. I’m not big on heavy-handed regulation, but if companies can’t be honest and responsible on their own, then some reasonable rules to protect privacy and prevent abuse make sense.

As someone who makes a living sifting through evidence and fine print, I think tech companies have a responsibility to treat user data like a serious liability, not a limitless asset. They should be required to explain clearly—without legalese—what they’re collecting, how it’s being used, and who it’s being sold or shared with, and users should have real control to opt out without being punished by a worse product. There also need to be strict legal limits on secondary uses of data (like profiling for insurance, employment, or credit) and meaningful penalties when companies are deceptive or negligent with people’s information. In a world where data can quietly shape people’s financial and personal lives, basic transparency and accountability shouldn’t be optional or buried in a 40-page terms-of-service.

Tech companies make huge profits from our data, so they should be legally required to be transparent about what they collect, how they use it, and who they sell it to. As someone who cares about justice and the environment, I see data privacy as part of respecting people and communities, not just as a “terms of service” box to check. Users should have real control over their information, including easy ways to opt out and delete data, and there should be strict limits on targeting kids and vulnerable groups. If they abuse our trust, there should be serious consequences, not just small fines they treat as a cost of doing business.

As someone who works in a public institution and cares deeply about community well-being, I believe tech companies should have a legal and moral duty to be fully transparent about what data they collect, how they use it, and with whom they share it. They should be required to get clear, informed consent, minimize the data they gather, and prioritize user privacy over profit, especially for vulnerable or less tech-savvy people. I also think strong government regulation is necessary to ensure companies can’t quietly exploit personal data in ways that undermine trust, dignity, or democratic participation.

As someone who loves new gadgets and works in sales, I get that data helps companies innovate and target what people actually want—but there have to be clear limits. As someone who grew up long before smartphones and social media, I find it troubling how casually tech companies scoop up our personal information. They have a responsibility to clearly explain what they’re collecting, get real consent, and never sell or share our data without our explicit permission. Especially for older folks like me, they should be held to strict laws that prevent abuse, protect our privacy, and impose serious penalties when they cross the line.

If tech companies are going to collect and profit from our data, they should have to spell out exactly what they’re taking and how they’re using it in plain language, not buried in some 20-page policy no one reads. I work hard for my money and my health, and I don’t want my personal info treated like a product that can be passed around without my say-so, especially when it could affect things like insurance or employment. They should give users real control—easy opt-outs, clear privacy settings, and strict limits on selling or sharing data—and be held legally accountable when they abuse that trust.

If tech companies are going to collect our data and make money off it, they should at least be straight-up about what they’re taking and exactly how they’re using it, in language regular people can actually understand. They should give us real control over our info—like easy ways to opt out or delete data—and not sell or share it in ways that could hurt us at school, work, or with insurance. And since not everyone has the same power or knowledge, they should have extra protections for younger users and people with disabilities so we’re not taken advantage of just because we don’t read a 20-page privacy policy.

I think if a company wants my data, they should ask in words kids and grown-ups can both understand, not tiny hard-to-read stuff. They should only take what they really need for the game or app to work and keep it super safe so no bad people can get it. If they make money from my data, they should tell my parents exactly how and give us choices to say yes or no.

I think if tech companies take our information, they should keep it super safe and not show it to strangers or use it to trick us. They should explain to our parents in simple words what they’re doing with our data and ask permission first. It’s important they don’t use kids’ data to make us want to buy stuff all the time or make us feel bad.

Tech companies should treat our personal data with the same care and honesty we expect from a trusted neighbor, not as something to exploit in secret. They ought to clearly explain what they’re collecting, get real permission, and give us simple ways to say no, especially for older people who didn’t grow up with all this technology. If they profit from our information, they should be held legally accountable when they misuse it or fail to protect it from hackers.

I think if companies take our information, they have to keep it super safe and not show it to strangers who might hurt us. They should always ask permission in a way kids and parents can understand, and not trick people with tiny words. If they make money from our data, they should use it to make things better and more fair for everyone, not just to get richer.

As someone who makes a living on information and trust in real estate, I think tech companies should be held to at least the same ethical standard I’m held to with my clients’ financial details. They should collect only what’s necessary, be completely transparent about how data is used and sold, and give people real control and consent—no sneaky fine print. I’d like to see strong regulations with real penalties, because without rules and accountability, the profit motive will always push them to cross lines that harm privacy and democracy.

Tech companies shouldn’t be able to treat our personal data like a free-for-all just because we clicked “I agree” on a 20-page terms sheet. They ought to be crystal clear about what they’re collecting, how they’re using it, and give us a real choice to opt out of anything beyond what’s necessary to make the service work. As a parent, I’m especially concerned about protecting kids’ data and think there should be strict limits and heavy penalties when companies misuse it. We don’t need more government running everything, but we do need common-sense rules that put families’ privacy ahead of Silicon Valley’s profits.

As someone who works every day to protect and support vulnerable kids, I think tech companies should treat user data—especially children’s data—with the same level of care we give to student records: clear consent, strict limits on what’s collected, and full transparency about how it’s used and who profits. Monetizing data shouldn’t come at the expense of people’s dignity or safety, and there must be strong protections against discrimination and exploitation, particularly for immigrants and marginalized communities. Tech firms should be legally and ethically accountable, with simple, accessible privacy controls instead of burying users in confusing fine print.

As someone who works in health care, I’m very conscious of how sensitive information can be and how much damage can be done when it’s mishandled. Tech companies should be held to a standard much closer to HIPAA-level protections: clear, truly informed consent; strict limits on how data can be shared or sold; and strong security requirements that are regularly audited. They profit enormously from our data, so they should be legally responsible when their practices harm people, and users should have an easy, default right to see, correct, and delete their data.

As someone who works in industry and cares a lot about what kind of world my kids grow up in, I think tech companies have a serious responsibility to collect only the data they truly need and to be completely transparent about how they use and profit from it. Users should have clear, simple choices about opting in or out, and our information should never be treated like a free-for-all resource that can be sold to the highest bidder without our informed consent. From an ethical and social justice standpoint, companies also need to make sure their data practices don’t unfairly target or exploit vulnerable groups, and they should be held legally accountable when they abuse people’s trust.

I think tech companies should have to ask clearly before they take our data, and explain it in simple words that kids and parents can understand, not in long, confusing rules. Since they can make money from our information, they should protect it like it’s something valuable that belongs to us, not them, and never sell or share it in ways that could embarrass us, hurt us, or put us in danger.

At my age, I’ve seen how powerful technology can be, but I’ve also seen how easily power gets abused if no one’s watching. Tech companies should be required to clearly explain what data they’re collecting, get real consent—not something buried in fine print—and give people meaningful control over how their information is used and sold. If they profit from our data, they should be held to strict privacy, security, and transparency standards, with tough penalties when they fail. Personal freedom and dignity depend on knowing that our lives aren’t being quietly packaged and traded behind our backs.

As someone who’s seen a lot of change in my 77 years, I think tech companies have a serious moral responsibility to treat our data like something sacred, not a product to be quietly squeezed for profit. They should be crystal clear about what they collect and how they use it, give us simple, honest choices to opt in or out, and be held legally accountable when they misuse or fail to protect that information. Data about our health, finances, or faith should be especially protected, and no one should be able to buy or sell it in ways that harm vulnerable folks or undermine democracy. If these companies are making money off us, the least they can do is respect our dignity and privacy every step of the way.

As someone who has spent a lifetime studying how human activity can quietly, cumulatively damage ecosystems, I see data collection in much the same way: invisible extractions that can seriously harm people and democracy if left unchecked. Tech companies should be legally required to minimize what they collect, explain it in plain language, obtain truly informed consent, and never sell or share data in ways that enable discrimination, manipulation, or environmental and social harm. At a minimum, users should have the right to see, correct, and delete their data, and independent public oversight—not just corporate ethics boards—should enforce these standards.

As someone who runs a small business and values both privacy and personal responsibility, I think tech companies should be upfront and honest about what data they collect and exactly how they’re making money off it. Users ought to give clear, informed consent, and companies should be held liable if they misuse data or fail to protect it from hackers. I don’t want big government micromanaging everything, but I do think we need some basic, common‑sense rules to keep these tech giants from taking advantage of folks who don’t realize how much of their lives is being tracked.

As someone who works in a creative industry where intellectual property and trust are everything, I think tech companies have a responsibility to treat user data more like a loan than a resource they own outright. They should be radically transparent about what they collect, get clear, informed consent, and strictly limit data use to purposes that genuinely benefit users—not just advertisers or shareholders. At a minimum, users should have easy control over their data, including the right to see, correct, and delete it. In a society already anxious and polarized, exploiting people’s digital lives without real accountability feels not just unethical, but socially dangerous.

I think tech companies should be straight-up about what data they’re taking and how they’re making money off it, instead of hiding everything in tiny print nobody reads. If they’re going to track us, they should need our clear permission, protect that info like it’s their own money, and not sell it in ways that can hurt people’s chances at jobs, school, or fair prices. Since so much of our lives, including our music and entertainment, is online now, they have a responsibility to respect our privacy and to be held accountable when they mess up.

Tech companies ought to treat user data the way an old-school insurer treats confidential claim files: as a trust, not a free-for-all. They should be required to get clear, plain-English consent, limit what they collect to what’s truly necessary, protect it with strong security, and be held accountable when they misuse it. I don’t object to businesses making a fair profit, but they shouldn’t be allowed to quietly build detailed profiles on people and sell them off like a commodity without transparency and meaningful control for the user.

As someone who works in public education, I see every day how important it is to protect young people and their information, and I think tech companies need to treat user data with the same seriousness we give to student records. At a minimum, they should be transparent about what they collect, limit it to what’s truly necessary, and get clear, meaningful consent before monetizing anything. They also have a responsibility to protect that data with strong security and to avoid practices that exploit people’s habits or vulnerabilities just to squeeze out more profit. In a democracy, we shouldn’t have to choose between using modern technology and preserving our privacy and dignity.

As someone who works with kids every day and cares a lot about fairness and community, I think tech companies have a responsibility to be radically transparent about what data they collect, how they use it, and who profits from it. They should treat users’ data like something they’re borrowing, not owning—requiring clear, simple consent, strong privacy protections, and strict limits on selling or sharing information, especially for vulnerable groups like children and low-income communities. If they’re making money off our data, there should also be accountability and regulation to ensure that’s not done in ways that deepen inequality, fuel misinformation, or harm the environment through irresponsible data practices.
